results.title: A Bat, a ball and a boy
results.brief_description: Famous Australian cricketers, including Sir Donald Bradman, Richie Benaud, Ray Lindwall, Len Hutton and Neil Harvey illustrate how to improve a boy’s game from batting to bowling to fielding. Includes archival footage of some of Australia’s greatest players.

results.title: A Banker in paradise
results.creator_credit: Jack Gardiner, John Kingsford-Smith and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: Produced for the Bank of NSW as part of its 150th anniversary celebrations. Shows the scenery and colourful life of Fiji and the activities of an officer providing banking services.

results.title: A Bandit in Baling = Ba Ling Qie Zei
results.creator_credit: Wang Yi and Pearl River Film Studio
results.brief_description:
In the late Qing Dynasty, veteran of the Taiping Rebellion, Liu Hedong runs a small sculpture shop with his daughter, Liu Yizhi at Baling. After the Taiping Rebellion failed, Liu only wants to have a quiet life with his daughter in the small town. However, a rich businessman, Mr. Yang came one day and asked Liu to duplicate a treasure of the town—Fan Zhongyan’s Travel Notes on Yueyang Building carved on twelve big wood pieces, placed in the Yueyang Building. Liu did that for Mr. Yang but later became suspicious of Yang’s purpose. He rushed to the Yueyang Building with his daughter only to find the authentic woodcarvings had been replaced by his work and the guard of the Building was killed. Liu reported this to the newly-appointed county magistrate, who ordered that all must be done to catch the thief. Liu, a kung-fu master himself, also tried to find the thief, but in the meantime, a couple of young ladies have been killed by darts that belonged to Liu. Liu was imprisoned, but was saved by his daughter together with a young man. They went to Mr. Yang’s boat and found the authentic woodcarving but were poisoned by an old man on the boat. It turned out that the thief was the county magistrate, who wanted to sell the woodcarving to foreigners. After a big fight, Liu with his daughter and the young man eventually killed the magistrate and Mr. Yang and saved the treasure.

Fan Zhongyan’s (AD. 989-1052, Song Dynasty) ‘Travel Notes on Yueyang Building’ is a very well-known prose and has a unique place in Chinese literature. Fan’s famous sentence in the prose, “one should be the first in his/her country to worry about state affairs, and the last to enjoy oneself” is widely quoted and has become the motto for many Chinese people.

The film well combines different genres such as suspense, martial arts and melodrama. The Pearl River Film Studio, based in Guangzhou, produced quite some commercially successful films and this is just one example. (3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; May 21, 2010)

results.title: A Baby's shoe
results.creator_credit: D.W. Griffith and American Mutoscope and Biograph Company
results.brief_description: An abandoned baby girl left on the doorstep of a wealthy family by her poor mother finds herself in strange circumstances years later when fate intervenes and she is rescued by a young man from a runaway horse - unbeknownst to her, the man is her brother. Cast includes Florence Lawrence, Owen Moore, Linda Arvidson, George Nichols, Anita Hendrie, Harry Solter, Mack Sennett. Silent film with English intertitles.

results.title: A Baby's day at twelve weeks
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Yale Clinic of Child Development
results.brief_description: The infant is followed through its domestic day from the time of its waking at six o’clock in the morning until the final breast feeding at ten o’clock at night. Presents dressing, bathing, feeding, daytime naps, play, and general care of the infant including an interpretation of the significance of various reactions. Narrated by Arnold Gesell.

results.title: A Baby's day at forty-eight weeks
results.creator_credit: Arnold Gesell, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Yale Clinic of Child Development
results.brief_description: Illustrates prescribed methods of infant care at 48 weeks. Demonstrations include bathing, feeding, playing, and sleeping. Emphasises the importance of cod liver oil and orange juice in the diet, and directs attention to the necessity of regular elimination. Explains the psychological implications and the educational significance of the infant’s everyday experiences at this age.
